text: Hey folks, I was wondering if anyone had used the `ExtremeStats.jl` package recently. <@UA3UH56HL> I saw that the github badge indicates the build is failing, but that could be for whatever reasons. I just figured I would check before starting.

text: Seems to only fail on Linux on some JLL dependency, perhaps that is already externally resolved? <https://github.com/JuliaEarth/ExtremeStats.jl/runs/1546134138?check_suite_focus=true#step:6:352>

text: <@U8D0QF5NZ> Oh thanks for jumping in. Hmm, JLL dependency. That seems to be a binarybuilder file, right. Good to know that this is the only test case that is failing, and nothing more critical. I can give it a try and see what happens.

elements.text: Oh thanks for jumping in. Hmm, JLL dependency. That seems to be a binarybuilder file, right. Good to know that this is the only test case that is failing, and nothing more critical. I can give it a try and see what happens.

text: Hi <@UDDSTBX19> let me know if you have any issues with the package. It should be working. Contributions are very welcome

elements.text: let me know if you have any issues with the package. It should be working. Contributions are very welcome

text: <@UA3UH56HL> Oh certainly I will. Are there any particular functionalities you are trying to expand on that package?

elements.text: Oh certainly I will. Are there any particular functionalities you are trying to expand on that package?

text: The current fitting method is maximum likelihood. There is an open issue for the method of moments which should be more stable  that would be an awesome contribution

elements.text: The current fitting method is maximum likelihood. There is an open issue for the method of moments which should be more stable  that would be an awesome contribution

text: Excellent. Let me take a look and get a feel for the package. EVT is still new to me. Also, how about bayesian methods for estimation of the parameters? Seems like we have so much bayesian infrastructure with Turing, that it would be a natural fit for EVT.

elements.text: Excellent. Let me take a look and get a feel for the package. EVT is still new to me. Also, how about bayesian methods for estimation of the parameters? Seems like we have so much bayesian infrastructure with Turing, that it would be a natural fit for EVT.

text: But of course, I will look at the Method of Moments too.

elements.text: But of course, I will look at the Method of Moments too.
